are not quite available uh in a service mesh today uh or at least you know with something
like seo and envoy is really being able to capture the protocol level or network level uh
metrics around round trip time so actually seeing the latency for tcp itself
uh you know also uh seeing re-transmissions that are happening at the tcp level and also for packet loss also
capturing udb traffic um as that occurs and you know that could definitely be something used for
you know video streaming services and things from that standpoint and also dns as a protocol as well
where uh you know quite often we have seen issues where dns has been problematic for particular
deployments where you know dns latency might be really high for looking up of particular services or
names or you might actually see failures uh in dns but it's not
completely obvious right off the bat that those failures are occurring in the application so those are network layer metrics that
we're not seeing today inside of a service mesh so istio envoy they're really primarily
designed to provide this application layer metrics which they're key and critical and important they
themselves but it's also very important to understand the network layer as well you know if you were deploying these
applications in an on-premise type environment or an environment where you control the network you could have visibility into this
information by looking at data coming from your switches and routers and things that you might have on premise
but now as you move to the cloud or most people are moving to the cloud for their kubernetes deployments and and such
when that occurs you don't have that same level of visibility into the network you can't see you know if there are tcp
issues that are occurring or going across uh you know the the routers or switchers in that network
so having visibility into this is really key to understanding you know what uh could impact your
application or services um you know you might all the suddenly and we've seen this
a few different times in a few different places where you know the the network between different zones within a given region
might become unstable or there might be a large number of re-transmissions you know and trying to attribute uh or
seeing that as sort of bubble up into an application issue trying to attribute that to the application or to the network
is definitely key and critical when troubleshooting those types of issues so to get to that level of information
you have to use something like ebpf to get this more detailed network data and jonathan will talk a bit more about

to occur and it's always critical and it's always um you know it's always very important to

uh you know when deploying a new service or using a service mesh in our environment

made use of the very well put together uh google cloud platform microservices demo
it's a set of a multi you know it's a handful of different services that call each other whenever a transaction occurs
it also has the redis backend as well for doing retrieval of data and storage of
data so there's a number of different service interactions that are occurring within the system
so we set up a just a very simple three node eks cluster inside of aws we made use of
c5 extra large instances and then also we deployed the latest
version of istio at the time of which i ran the benchmark uh which was a month or so ago
uh using version one uh six five uh we made sure to use the default
profile you know a lot of times when people are trying istio out they'll use the demo profile that comes with a lot of other
great sort of tooling and other components to allow for further
kind of introspection of data within the system but we went with the default which is what's recommended for production level
uh workloads and then the thing that's also fantastic about this particular um
bench or this particular microservices demo is it actually comes with its own load generating load generator
uh which is locus um so instead of running locus as part of the application
itself we actually moved locus to its own separate instance within the same zone
within the same region of the kubernetes cluster and we were simulating 500 users using locus
which is you know using the pattern and sort of the configuration file that's defined by the
this microservices demo so you know this is something that you could very easily reproduce yourself uh and you know
easily run you know this particular benchmark within your own environment as well
so with that type of setup we went ahead and started to benchmark uh the application
so the other great thing about this microservices demo is that it can be deployed you know with
just sort of a normal sort of standard configuration and then it also does come with the additional istio configurations too
as well to be deployed you know using istio for ingress and and for the interactions of
the services so we first deployed it without uh just sort of as a baseline standard
application and across the cluster we saw about 13
cpu utilization and a p50 response time of 16 milliseconds for our p90 response
time we saw about 33 milliseconds you know this is about standard about kind of what you would expect for an application
uh like this where there's a number of interactions and things from that perspective you know it kind of in line with uh sort
of you know what you would expect out of it we then redeployed the application uh
using uh or deployed istio to the cluster redeploy the application
to make use of istio and then re-ran our tests on the cluster as well and what we saw
for cpu utilization is we saw a increase of nearly 70 percent for cpu utilization
now with a smaller cluster like this you know there is you definitely additional sort of
overhead that is paid a little bit more for a smaller cluster versus if this was to scale out to a
larger cluster but it does go to show that there is you know a a significant increase in overall cpu
utilization for the application once you know once seo envoy was deployed to it
the other place that we saw uh pretty large gains was around the p50 response
time we actually saw it go from 16 milliseconds to 25 milliseconds so you know over a 50 increase
and you know this this might be uh something that you know you're uh some you know for particular use cases
and workloads this might be perfectly acceptable you know for others you know you might want to try to
minimize your latency as much as possible so it's really just sort of that you know making that consideration or taking
this into consideration of you know the additional latency that will that could possibly be added
when using something like seo envoy for your application we also saw a p90 response time of about
48 milliseconds which is 45 increase over the baseline application
so you know definitely uh you know non-trivial uh increase in overhead and latency that
uh you know was added for using seo um and you know it gives you kind of a
general idea of sort of what we saw when uh you know we deployed the application uh you know
just with the baseline versus using sdo and envoy so with that let's talk about uh evpf
and how ebpf could be used and for this section i'm going to hand it off to uh jonathan uh so that he can take us

take over great thank you rocco um so evp let me tell you a little bit
about it um evpf has been around for since uh 2013 2014 um with the introduction of
the bpf system called to kernel 318 so this has been around for a
while since kernel 4-4 there has been enough btf support
machinery to write substantial programs um and this has been back ported to
rail 76 so kernels as early as 310. what dpf allows user space programs is
to run tiny snippets of code when different kernel events happen so it could be when a packet is received
or when a process is started a container is started a container finishes and so on any kernel event you can run some code
on this is great for telemetry collection
because you can use ebpf to get from the operating system a stream of
important events where you choose what events are important to you and you can get a stream instead of
trying to recover this information from the operating system using command line tools or
other system calls so which which could be really expensive in number of cpu cycles and
and give you incomplete information um evpf also gives uh
these visibility platforms more access into internal data structures so it is possible to get information
about how the system is behaving what is happening to your sockets to your processes to your containers
uh that is just inaccessible from user space vpf is great because there are
uh very extensive mechanisms to make it safe and fast safety wise evpf the kernel comes with
an in-kernel verifier the it's it's a mechanism that as you load etf
programs the kernel makes sure that first there are no infinite loops in it
those are not allowed uh it cannot access invalid memory and crash your system and in fact in many of the settings
where you want to extract telemetry you gif code runs in read-only mode it cannot change any memory into your
kernel so this has great stability benefits you know compared to kernel modules for example where you can get
similar visibility um so evie is extremely safe it is also very fast low overhead uh the kernel has a
just-in-time compiler that transforms uh the evpf code into
very efficient machine code so you can run this you can run instrumentation very
pervasively with very low impact on your performance
there are open source projects that provide some bpf tooling one of them is bcc
that is a major project i encourage everybody to to go and visit it read a little bit

in the tcp top tool you can see here ipv4 send byte is

throughput as it's reading uh you should notice that kind of the kernel data structure

the code clears the kernel data structures but what could happen is what does

there's many strengths that that we have talked about uh you know the detailed application metrics are you
know are definitely useful especially understanding long-lived connections and making sure that they're
balanced across the system and things from that perspective uh you know security encryption and

things that you do get with using a service mesh but there is that resource overhead that that you do

also the network layer metrics are not readily available uh with something like this which especially in cloud type

and you know getting to that information could typically be pretty pretty difficult or pretty costly in the
sense of you know if you were on something like amazon with uh using flow logs or vpc flow logs
you're capturing that information and saying to s3 you know is definitely an additional cost as well
now on the ebpf trade-offs the the strengths are you know there is uh since we are running at the kernel
level and capturing events at the kernel and you know there's we can get very detailed
uh network layer metrics uh it can be very optimized for minimal impact since we're
uh you know just reading sort of events or capturing events as they occur within the system
the weakness is is like there is no full open source solution uh for capturing and using this
information today there are some projects out there like psyllium and such that are making use of
bppf uh to help with portions of the service mesh but um you're just a tooling just
focusing on the observability side of things you know there's not a um you know
there are kind of pieces out there today but not a full solution that's available from the open source project
so bringing it all together you know using a service mesh along with ebpf
really allows for that deep observability on both the from an application standpoint and also
from a network standpoint so being able to combine these metrics from both systems it
really provides you sort of a complete view of the environment um you know if you can actually take a

in the environment you know things from that perspective uh which you know using the combination of both these metrics
